structured.title: Sermon Emphasizes Knowing the True Jesus
structured.overview: The content is a sermon-style exhortation stressing that salvation hinges on who Jesus is, not only on what he did. The speaker insists that many can speak about Christ yet be wrong about him, warning that a slightly altered or reshaped Jesus is a false savior who cannot save. Listeners are urged, following the apostle John, to "test" what is confessed about Jesus rather than focus on preaching style or tone. The message highlights the early church’s fierce defense of orthodox Christology, including the creeds and willingness to suffer exile and death, as evidence that Christianity is founded on rightly knowing the real Christ, not merely admiring him.

apps_results.content:
## Core Warning  
- Many false prophets have gone into the world  
- Not every “Jesus” spoken of is the real Jesus  
- You can preach Jesus yet proclaim a different savior  

## Central Truth About Salvation  
- Salvation depends on who Jesus is  
- Not only on what Jesus did on the cross  
- A wrong view of Jesus means no true salvation  

## Testing Teaching About Jesus  
- Test what is confessed about Jesus, not style  
- Tone, calmness, passion do not prove truth  
- Getting Jesus wrong means trusting one who can't save  

## Dangers of a “Slightly Different” Jesus  
- A wrong Jesus cannot save you  
- A slightly altered Jesus cannot reconcile you to God  
- A reshaped Jesus cannot bring you to God  

## Early Church Response  
- Early Christians wrote creeds to guard doctrine  
- They accepted exile, opposition, even death over compromise  
- They knew Christianity is not mere admiration of Jesus  

## Next Steps  
- Examine what is taught about who Jesus is  
- Compare every teaching with Scripture’s description of Jesus  
- Reject any version of Jesus that differs from Scripture
